Senators use filibusters as a tool to block or delay action on legislation or nominations. The main reason senators use the filibuster is to try to prevent a bill or nomination from being passed or approved, either to protect their own interests or to influence the outcome of a decision.

In many cases, senators use the filibuster as a way to force negotiation and compromise on the issues being debated. They may want to see changes made to a bill or amendment, or they may want to use the filibuster to draw attention to a specific issue or to sway public opinion.

While the filibuster can be effective in delaying or blocking action, it can also cause significant gridlock and slow down the legislative process. In recent years, there has been ongoing debate over whether the filibuster should be reformed or eliminated altogether, as it has been criticized for contributing to political polarization and decreasing the ability of government to respond to pressing issues.
